newsitem.title: UK: FOCUS - Japan report boosts dollar,Eurobourses mixed.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - Japan report boosts dollar,Eurobourses mixed.

text.p: A weak survey of Japanese business sentiment boosted the dollar on Wednesday and European bourses were mixed, with London and Frankfurt up, helped by a firm Wall Street, but Paris down on currency and strike worries.

At 1100 GMT the dollar was trading at around 108.38 yen, up from its European close on Tuesday of 107.55 after the Bank of Japan's quarterly corporate survey, or "tankan", showed the diffusion index for major manufacturers -- an important gauge of business sentiment -- falling to minus seven in August from minus three in the previous survey in May.
The unexpected figures convinced markets that Japanese interest rates would stay at rock-bottom levels -- weakening the yen. The Japanese discount rate is currently at a record low of 0.5 percent.
The BOJ sought to put the best face on the data which defied economists' predictions of improving sentiment and was the first decline in business sentiment in a year.
A BOJ spokesman said "the doors to the recovery have not been shut...the recovery is still continuing." These remarks gave the yen some backbone and the dollar failed to build on its gains.
Dealers said it would be hard for the dollar to break higher against the yen and it was likely to trade in narrow ranges for the rest of the day.

"The dollar's gains were less than spectacular, suggesting that while it's likely to benefit from revised Japanese rate expectations, a breakout from the established trading range doesn't appear likely," said currency economist Klaus Baader.

On the European bourses, London shares added to early gains boosted by Wall Street. They climbed from the start, with the blue chip FTSE 100 index hitting a new peak of 3,919.7 early in the day before dropping back slightly.

One focus was British Airways, which rebounded after fears faded that the cancellation of "open skies" talks between the U.S. Transportation Department and the British government may jeopardise its tie-up with American Airlines.
The conclusion of an open skies agreement had been made a prerequisite of the proposed link-up by the U.S.
In Frankfurt firmer German debt and the higher close on Wall Street overnight gave German equities a boost early on, but dealers said the soft dollar/mark still weighed on sentiment.

By contrast French stocks opened lower and extended their losses to more than one percent in morning trading, falling through the 2000 point resistance level on the main CAC-40 index. Dealers blamed a weakening franc and worries about the 1997 budget and possible autumn strikes

Louis Viannet, leader of France's Communist-led CGT union, criticised government plans for spending cuts in the 1997 budget on Wednesday and warned of labour unrest as France gets back to work after the holidays.
Dealers said shares were also affected by a slippage in bond prices due to lower than expected June industrial production, showing the economy was still faltering.
CURRENCIES AT 1100 GMT
The dollar was at 108.35 yen and 1.4785 marks compared with Tuesday's European close of 107.78 yen and 1.4779 marks
STOCK MARKETS AT 1100 GMT
The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading British shares had risen 8.3 points to 3,914.0.
In Paris, the CAC-40 share index dropped 21.02 to 1,996.97.
The 30-share DAX index in Frankfurt was up 5.31 at 2,564.15.
PRECIOUS METALS
Gold fixed at $388.65 versus $388.55 at Tuesday's London close. Silver was at $5.23, down a cent.
